question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
Is

\[g(x) = \frac{1}{\sin (x)}\] continuous on the interval
$(-\infty, \infty)$? Why or why not?
sols:
In order for a function to be continuous on the interval
$( - \infty, \infty )$ it must be defined everywhere. However, in the
previous part of the question, we just showed that \emph{g} is not
defined at an infinite number of points. Thus \emph{g} is not continuous
on $(- \infty, \infty)$.
hints:
Recall the answer from part (a) of this question. Does one of those
requirements fail?
